Studying At The University Of Abertay Dundee: What To Expect
Money On Arrival and Opening Bank Accounts
SCOPE (The Student Centre for Opportunities in Part Time Employment)
Studying At The University Of Abertay Dundee: What To Expect
<span class="style1">You will have to attend lectures each week - usually one for each of your four modules in each semester. Lectures are for all the students taking one module
column2: so numbers may be large. For each module you will need to attend a tutorial. This is a smaller group where you have a chance to develop topics from lectures. You are expected to give your own views and get involved in discussion.

column1: For many programmes you will also have to attend a practical or lab session.
Will I need to buy a lot of books?

The University Library is well-stocked and has good systems to make sure there are books for everyone (eg by limiting borrowing to a day or a few hours). It is a good idea to buy key textbooks. Sometimes you can buy second-hand copies.
For most modules the assessment is by timed examination at the end of the semester and by coursework.
Coursework may be a long essay
column4: a group project or an oral presentation. You may have several weeks to complete coursework. For coursework you are expected to read about the topic and develop your own ideas and opinions about it.

column1: <span class="style1">You can ask your lecturers to explain something in a lecture or in a tutorial. You can also make an appointment to discuss questions with your lecturer. Every student has a personal tutor to whom they can go with any academic or other problems. Each semester you will meet your personal tutor - even if you have no problems
column2: to talk about your progress on your course.

column1: The University Student Academic Support centre also runs workshops on examination technique
I really want to improve my English. How can I do this?
<span class="style1">You can take the Pre-sessional Programme for 4 weeks or 8 weeks between July and September. This Programme will help you to improve your English
column2: learn how to study for a British degree
column3: learn how to write academic English and also help you to settle in to life in Dundee.

column1: Read more about our English language programmes.
Is my course and Abertay University recognised through out Scotland and the UK?
<span class="style1">Abertay students and graduates have many reasons to be proud of the universities
growing success and reputation. Abertay understands the importance of
good IT and computing facilities and the state of the art library and
new student centre epitomizes the universities dedication to its students
and learning environment. We typically spend more on computers than
Cambridge University. Read more good reasons to be part of Abertay.

Each student will have a personal tutor in their school that they can ask for help. Some departments have tutors specifically for international students so feel free to approach the academic staff for assistance.
<span class="style1">Student Services is a division within the university which provides services including personal counselling
column3: assistance with accommodation problems and advice and welfare from immigration to financial problems.

column1: Money On Arrival and Opening Bank Accounts
<span class="style1">You will need approximately £150 in British currency on arrival in the UK. This is to pay for transport
column2: meals and perhaps overnight accommodation for the first few days. Do not carry any more than this in case it gets lost or stolen. It is a good idea to bring some travellers cheques with you for emergencies; they can be cashed at an airport Bureau de Change office or at a bank.

column1: Bringing money to the UK can be a problem if you do not plan ahead.   There are a number of ways of getting money into the country
column2: but even the quickest method can take one or two days for the transfer arrangements to be completed. The various options open to you are listed below:

column1: <span class="style1">Most banks in the UK will accept MasterCard
column3: Eurocard or Visa. These can be used to withdraw cash from cash dispensing machines and enable you to obtain money when you first arrive and before you have opened a bank account
column4: provided you know the PIN (Personal Identification Number of the card).

column1: <span class="style1">This is one of the quickest ways of transferring money from a bank in your country to one in the UK. You can use this method only when you have opened a bank account in the UK. It can be quite expensive and the transfer must be organised with your bank at home either by yourself
column3: via fax or through you parents at home. It is therefore very useful to bring your bank's telephone and fax number with you in case you need to organise this type of transfer.

column1: <span class="style1">Travellers cheques are very useful because they can be changed into sterling at a bureau de change
column2: bank or hotel (although not all hotels offer this facility) enabling you to obtain money before you have organised a bank account.

column1: <span class="style1">You may consider opening a bank account in the UK before you arrive. The advantage of doing this is that it is easy to make payments in advance of your arrival
column3: paying a deposit in order to secure a private flat which can involve quite a lot of money. It is also useful in obtaining a Visa (should you require one)
column4: as you will be able to show your financial status in sterling

column1: If you are planning on opening a bank account when you arrive at the University it is important that you have the following documents ready as this will speed up the process of opening a bank account.
• Letter from the University confirming your local address/student status.

column2: you will be required to present your original lease or contract.

column1: <span class="style1">There are a number of things you might like to consider before deciding whether or not to bring your family with you to the UK. Apart from the obvious increase in living expenses to cover the cost of your family living here
column3: which you should bear in mind. If you wish to bring your wife/husband and/or children it is usually easier to apply for their visa at the same time as your own.

column1: In normal circumstances the wife or husband of an international student will be given permission to enter and remain with his or her partner for the duration of the course. They will also be able to work as long as your partner's right to work is restricted but not prohibited. If the stamp in the passport states that employment is prohibited it is possible to change this by asking the permission of the relevant Secretary of State. Your husband or wife can work full-time whilst you are a student in the UK.
<span class="style1">Normally all children under the age of 18 can enter and remain in the UK for as long as their student parent has permission to stay
column2: providing you have sufficient funds available to support and house them.

column1: There are a number of nurseries/playgroups for small children in Dundee. Childcare for this age group is expensive so do take this into consideration.
<span class="style1">Children aged 5 - 16 are required by law to go to school and will be entitled to free schooling. For details of schools in the Dundee area contact Dundee City Council

<span class="style1">All students enrolling on an undergraduate or postgraduate course do not have to pay for treatment under the National Health Service (NHS). This includes general medical treatment and any hospital or emergency treatment. All students are expected to pay for medicines
column2: most dental treatment and eye tests including the prescription of glasses or contact lenses.

column1: IMPORTANT: You should still purchase health/medical insurance in case you need to be repatriated to your country to continue hospitalisation and to be close to family. If you do not have this insurance it can cost you £5000+ to be airlifted home. The husband/wife and dependents of eligible international students are also eligible for NHS treatment.

When you arrive at the university it is important you register with a doctor as quickly as possible. There is a Student Health Drop In Session available at certain times throughout the week on The University campus.

<span class="style1">The stamp in your passport will tell you whether you are allowed to work part-time or during vacations in this country. Nearly all international students are now able to work part time whilst studying. For most students
column2: if you wish to work part time during your studies you must ensure that you have the correct stamp in your passport. If your stamp confirms that you are restricted but not prohibited from work you will be entitled to work up to a maximum of 20 hours during term time and up to as many as 40 hours during vacation periods.

column1: You will be required to obtain a National Insurance Number in order for your employer to correctly record any National Insurance Contributions. To apply for a National Insurance Number in the United Kingdom if you do not already have one please contact you're nearest Department for Work and Pensions www.dwp.gov.uk or www.jobcentreplus.gov.uk for more details.
The Workers Registration Scheme will affect some European students.

column2: most nationals of the new member states (except Cyprus and Malta): who wish to work for an employer for more than 1 month will be subject to the Accession State Worker Registration Scheme. If you are subject to the scheme you will be required to register if you plan to work for more than 1 month for an employer in the UK.

column1: Once you have been working legally in the UK for 12 months without a break you will have full rights of free movement. You can get an EEA residence permit confirming your status.
Nationals of Malta and Cyprus working in the UK can apply for a residence permit now.

Please note: You can only complete a WRS application once you have commenced work and it must be made within the first month of work or you will be working illegally and the employer is committing a criminal offence. Complete a Workers Registration Scheme application form providing your name
column4: nationality and your employment details along with £50.00 registration fee and your passport or identity card. On successful application you will be provided with a registration card with photographic ID and a registration certificate number.

column1: If you wish to change employer you will have to apply for a fresh certificate but you will NOT have to pay the £50.00 registration fee again. The employer will also be sent a copy of the registration certificate.
To request an application form telephone 08705 210 224 or log onto www.workingintheuk.gov.uk/working in the uk/en/homepage.html and download an application form.
For more information please contact the International Student Advisor on advisory@abertay.ac.uk
Nationals from the new member states (except Cyprus and Malta) including the Czech Republic
column8: please note that the application fee will increase from Â£50.00 to Â£70.00 on the 1st of October 2005.

column1: <span class="style1">Many international students choose to work in the UK during their studies. Part-time employment can provide an opportunity for you to make new friends and offer you the chance to learn more about the city and it's people. Other benefits include
column2: practice at making applications and improving your language skills - whilst earning extra cash of course!

column1: The Careers Service at Abertay can assist you with your search for a part-time job as well as offer practical advice and guidance. Our  job shop  advertises vacancies from a range of employers in the local area - that are suitable for students. Further
column2: we can advise on other ways of finding employment - through the local job centre or recruitment agencies for example and help with completing your application or C.V. We cannot unfortunately
column3: find jobs for individuals or forward your C.V on to an employer - this you must do yourself.

column1: To find out more about the careers service go to Careers.
